review: The newer your tv and the more refresh cycles you have, the better this gismo works. It's just genius and so freeing!!!! Is it theatrical quality? NO, but who cares. I do a lot of presentations and guided mediations (audio and video atmosphere) and I use the gismo. If you already have digitally created the audio and video, this is the way to go. Have not tried PowerPoint with it, because I keep Microsoft products to the bare minimum on my equipment, but the gismo might work with that too. I don't know.Kudos to Google for inventing something so practical.
author: Marilyn

review: As an avid user of many of the supported applications for the Chromecast, I have to say I love it.Some background.  I have tried cable TV, but hate the lack of on demand.  Tried mobile viewing, but prefer my big screen.  Have a smart TV, but the interface is slow and clunky.  Tried Roku 3, a better interface, but sill too many buttons to watch a show.This lets me use interfaces designed to take full advantage of touch controls and keyboards, making finding and playing shows easy, while allowing me to push that content to any HDMI enabled screen.  Netflix works great, though I miss the auto-forward.  Hulu works good.  Plex is absolutely killer.  All in all lots of functionality for the price.That said there are some negatives.  This is clearly revision 1 hardware, I can't use it in my bedroom despite having no problem with my Roku (moved from the living room) or 2 laptops.  There are issues maintaining a connection freqently, with inconsistent results when reconnecting.  The SDK is finally out, but I haven't seen any new killer apps yet.  This is still a beta product, but with potential to shake the media consumption world once the content providers get behind it.I hope to see a day where all my media apps have a push to chromecast button.  Where I can jump between providers apps (FOX, Hulu, ABC, HBO etc.) and watch my shows using a natural interface.  With a cheap tablet replacing my old universal remote.
